title: Chess Analysis
description:
Project Name: Chess Analyzer AI Agent

Objective:
Create a full-stack AI backend for a Chess Analyzer web app with the following workflow:
1. Accept a Chess.com username.
2. Fetch the last 10 games for that user.
3. Let the user select one game to analyze.
4. Analyze the selected game using Stockfish (or equivalent chess engine) and return detailed move-by-move evaluation.
5. Return structured JSON + natural-language explanations + a summary report with improvement tips.

Workflow Details:

Step 1: Fetch Last 10 Games
- Input: { "username": "chessUser" }
- Validate username exists on Chess.com.
- Fetch last 10 games with the following details:
  - game_id
  - date
  - opponent
  - result (Win/Loss/Draw)
  - link
- Output Example:
[
  { "game_id": "123456789", "date": "2025-09-27", "opponent": "Hikaru", "result": "Win", "link": "https://www.chess.com/game/live/123456789" },
  ...
]

Step 2: Game Selection
- Input: { "game_id": "123456789" }
- Fetch PGN or move list for the selected game.
- Parse moves using chess.js or equivalent library.
- Output Example:
{ "game_id": "123456789", "moves": ["e4","e5","Nf3","Nc6", ...] }

Step 3: Move Analysis (Key Part)
- For each move, perform engine evaluation:
  - Calculate centipawn loss.
  - Suggest best move.
  - Classify as Blunder (>200 cp), Mistake (100‚Äì200 cp), or Inaccuracy (50‚Äì100 cp).
- Generate natural-language explanations for key moves:
  - Example: "This knight move slightly weakens your central control."
- Track move number, player, move notation.
- Output Example for a move:
{
  "move_number": 12,
  "player": "White",
  "move": "Nc6",
  "evaluation": -0.25,
  "best_move": "Nf6",
  "blunder": false,
  "mistake": false,
  "inaccuracy": true,
  "explanation": "This move slightly weakens your central control."
}

Step 4: Summary Report
- Aggregate analysis for entire game:
  - Accuracy (%)
  - Total mistakes, blunders, inaccuracies
  - Opening name + variation
  - Key moments (array of strings)
  - Summary paragraph in beginner-friendly language
  - Improvement tips (array of strings)
- Output Example:
{
  "game_id": "123456789",
  "accuracy": "87%",
  "mistakes": 2,
  "blunders": 1,
  "inaccuracies": 3,
  "opening": "Sicilian Defense, Najdorf Variation",
  "key_moments": [
    "Move 12: Inaccuracy ‚Äì Allowed isolated pawn.",
    "Move 19: Blunder ‚Äì Missed defending the knight.",
    "Move 28: Excellent move ‚Äì Found a winning exchange."
  ],
  "summary": "You played a sharp Sicilian opening. The middle game had some mistakes, but the endgame was strong. Focus on defending central pawns in similar positions.",
  "tips": [
    "Always check for opponent forks before moving the queen.",
    "Control the center with pawns during early moves.",
    "Look for opportunities to trade pieces when ahead in material."
  ]
}

API Endpoints:
1. /fetch-games
   - Method: POST
   - Input: { "username": "chessUser" }
   - Output: JSON list of last 10 games
2. /analyze-game
   - Method: POST
   - Input: { "game_id": "123456789" } or { "pgn": "PGN text" }
   - Output: Move-by-move JSON + summary report

Optional Features:
- Export report as PDF or Markdown
- Game comparison mode (compare two games side-by-side)
- Auto-fetch games via scraping if API limits exist
- Deployment automation: GitHub ‚Üí Vercel

Technical Notes:
- Language: TypeScript / Node.js
- Framework: Express.js
- Use chess.js for move parsing
- Stockfish via WebAssembly or external engine
- Ensure fast response and scalability
- Include clear error handling for invalid username, missing game, or engine errors

Deliverable:
A single AI agent that:
1. Takes a username ‚Üí fetches last 10 games
2. Lets user select a game ‚Üí fetches PGN
3. Analyzes moves ‚Üí returns JSON + natural-language explanations
4. Generates summary report + improvement tips
5. Optional: export report, deployment automation, game comparison

title: cyber security in health care sector:protecting patient data
description: Cybersecurity in the healthcare sector is very important because hospitals and clinics store a large amount of patient information digitally. This data includes personal details, medical history, and treatment records, which must be kept safe from hackers and unauthorized access. As healthcare systems use technologies like electronic health records, cloud storage, and connected medical devices, they become more vulnerable to cyberattacks such as ransomware, phishing, and data theft. Protecting patient data helps maintain privacy and trust between patients and healthcare providers. To improve security, hospitals should use strong passwords, data encryption, firewalls, and regular system updates. Training staff to recognize security risks is also essential. Following government data protection rules ensures that patient information is handled safely. In short, cybersecurity plays a key role in keeping healthcare systems secure, ensuring smooth hospital operations, and protecting the sensitive information of every patient.

description:
The Jewellery Sales Insights Dashboard is a data analysis and visualization project developed using Python and Streamlit in Google Colab. The main objective of this project is to analyze jewellery sales data and represent it through an interactive and visually appealing dashboard that helps business owners make better decisions.

The project uses a Jewellery Sales Dataset, which contains information such as product category (like Rings, Earrings, Bridal, Fancy), region, date, and total sales. The system processes this data to display insightful trends, comparative graphs, and summaries that show the overall business performance.

By using Streamlit, the project provides a React.js‚Äìlike web interface that allows users to easily explore the data through dropdown filters, charts, and tables. The interface is clean, interactive, and requires no manual coding once deployed ‚Äî it runs entirely online through Google Colab with the help of Ngrok to generate a live web link.

The dashboard includes:

Product-wise and Region-wise sales comparison

Sales trends over time

Product distribution using pie charts

Statistical summary of total sales and performance

Insights highlighting top-selling jewellery categories and profitable regions

title: Women safety application using AI
description:
The android app lets you:

Save phone numbers of your trusted relatives in your local storage
Send Message with live location and make phone call by just tapping the power button three times
Start Siren alarm by just tapping the power button again three times to deviate the culprit
Stop Siren alarm by just tapping the power button again three times
Detect any hidden spy camera by just scanning the suspected places
Get the tips on manual detection of spy cameras
Read women's empowerement and struggle related news to get empowered
Contact Us Feature
Share app feature
Brief Process Flow
When we tap the launcher icon,then a splash screen merged with the lotttie animations is displayed.
After that we need to give some permissions to the app then the home screen with 7 CardView Buttons is displayed.
These Seven Card View buttons include Emergency SOS ,Hidden Camera Detector, women's News ,Siren Alarm, App Tour, About Us, Share and save lives.
When we enter into :-
1.Emergency SOS service then phone no. of relatives is saved by the help of shared preferences in the form of key value pair and when we tap on the try it button then a phone call is made by the help of implicit intent and a message is sent by the help of SMS Manager class and this message is also embedded with the live location of the user which is provided by the help of fusedlocationprovider client API.

Now,As we also need to trigger this functionality even when the phone is locked .So, whenever the phone is in locked state then the app is in paused state therefore we can't perform any action in background .So a background service is registered inside the app so that even if the phone is in locked state some functionalities could get executed.
Now,A broadcast receiver is registered inside the background service in order to receive the broadcast message from OS about the screen ON/OFF state to count the power button tap count.
And a timer also gets started when we tap the power button first time and if we tap power button three times then the try it fuinctionality is executed and if tapped six times before 30 secs then a siren alarm gets started in order to deviate the culprit and if again tapped power button 3 times then alarm will stop.
Hidden camera detector then we must be knowing that all the electronic cameras emit electromagnetic radiations and these electromagnetic radiations strength in all three directions are detected by the magnetometer sensor of our phone and if its resultant is greater than a certain range then the phone starts beeping.
3.Women‚Äôs News then it shows only women‚Äôs news screen which is populated by the data of a news api fetched by the help of retrofit library.

4.Siren Alarm then this screen starts a siren alarm in looping by the help of media player API.

5.About Us then user can read about us and can also contact us by the help of implicit intents.

6.App tour then get the whole tour of the app.

7.Share app then they can share and save lives.

 When the siren button is pressed the call was going from our saved contact.To bulid a full working website.the hidden camera option is not working please clear the fault,the siren is a touching format but I not expect that .The siren button 3 times click the phone's lock button(physical)And then siren button is on and going call from saved contacts.Then use voice assistant and say "Help me" With critical voice analysis then call was going near police station and family members.Call is not going ,only showing the number in the dial pad.
additionalNotes: The user raises voice "help me" then automatically call connect to the saved numbers and near police station and send notification.also location are shared.using AI voice recognition

The To-Do App is a simple yet powerful task management system built using the MEAN stack (MongoDB, Express, Angular, and Node.js). It allows users to efficiently create, manage, and track their daily tasks in an organized manner.

The application provides a clean and responsive Angular frontend for users to interact with, while the backend is powered by Node.js and Express.js for handling API requests. title: BoldandItalic
description:
1 ‚Äî High-level architecture

Components

DualEditor (container): holds toggle, toolbars, status, AceEditor and VisualEditor.

AceEditor (existing Ace instance): shows LaTeX source.

VisualEditor (DOM or virtual DOM): renders HTML converted from LaTeX AST and is editable.

Converter (service): two-way converter: LaTeX AST ‚Üî HTML DOM fragment.

SyncEngine (service): minimal-diff synchronization, selection mapping, operation generator.

HistoryEngine: undo/redo stack of granular operations (OT-like or diffs).

TableManager: create/generate HTML table + LaTeX code and handle table context menu operations.

Data model

Canonical model: LaTeX AST (not raw string). Keep this as the single source of truth in memory.

Derived: LaTeX source string (for Ace) and HTML DOM (for Visual) are views rendered from AST.

All user edits in either editor are mapped to atomic modifications to the AST, then rendered to both views.

Why AST as single source? It lets you generate minimal LaTeX code changes from DOM edits and keep semantic mapping (styles ‚Üí macros).

2 ‚Äî Converter strategy (LaTeX AST ‚Üî HTML)

Approach

Use or build a LaTeX parser to produce a structured AST (nodes: text, macro, environment, group, table, list, etc.).

Write canonical mapping functions:

astToHtmlNode(astNode) -> HTMLElement | VirtualNode

htmlRangeToAstEdit(rangeInDom) -> AstEdit { path, startOffset, endOffset, newAstFragment }

astToLatexString(ast) -> string

Keep mapping metadata when rendering HTML: attach data-ast-path attributes to DOM nodes representing the AST node path (e.g. 0.3.2) and store node lengths so you can map cursor positions back to AST offsets.

Minimal change edits

When user edits selection in Visual, compute the edited DOM fragment, translate the fragment into AST nodes, create an AstEdit patch (replace AST range with new AST fragment) and apply.

The SyncEngine will compute new LaTeX string and call Ace:
editor.session.replace(lastRangeOfChange, newLatexStringForPatch) ‚Äî ensure Ace‚Äôs lastRangeOfChange equals old text span in Ace.

3 ‚Äî Selection & cursor mapping (core problem)

Key idea: Attach stable position references to DOM and LaTeX.

Implementation details

AST path + offsets: Each AST text node stores its length. When rendering HTML, wrap text nodes in spans with data-ast-path="0.2.1" and data-offset-start="5" data-offset-end="10" for fast mapping.

On selection in VisualEditor:

Get selection range. Find nearest ancestor with data-ast-path. Compute start path + offset within node by walking text nodes.

Convert (path, offset) to AST global position (character index or node index+offset).

Create AST patch:

Parse the new DOM fragment from selection into AST fragment.

Replace only the AST range corresponding to selection.

Apply patch:

ast.applyPatch(patch) -> new AST.

Re-render HTML for minimal affected subtree.

Generate minimal LaTeX string for only that replaced AST range (not full doc), and compute the corresponding Ace Range (character indices) to call editor.session.replace(range, newLatexForPatch).

When editing in Ace (LaTeX text changes):

Use incremental parser or re-parse affected region to produce AST patch and apply to AST.

Re-render only affected HTML subtree.

Important: To compute Ace Range for a patch, you must know the start and end character positions of the corresponding LaTeX text in the Ace buffer; maintain an index mapping from AST to LaTeX character offsets (update on each AST edit).

4 ‚Äî Operations / toolbar commands (bold, italic, list, indent, align, table, etc.)

General pattern

Compute selection in AST (use selection mapping above).

Generate an AST transformation (wrap nodes in macro node for \textbf{}, \textit{}, or for lists create environment nodes).

Apply patch to AST, render delta in Visual, and patch Ace with minimal LaTeX string replacement.

Examples

Bold

AST transform: wrap selection AST nodes into { \textbf{ <selection> } } or a macro node with name textbf.

Call applyPatch() ‚Üí renderDelta() ‚Üí aceReplace().

List style (apply enumerate/itemize)

If selection lines already in an itemize/enumerate, remove that environment. If mixed, replace siblings accordingly.

Enforce no nested lists unless user explicitly indent-lines (convert to nested environment carefully).

Align / Indent

Map to macro or environment as your LaTeX style convention (e.g., \begin{flushleft} or macros). Or render as CSS in HTML with metadata to preserve semantic mapping.

For indent, transform AST by applying indent attribute to block node. LaTeX mapping could be \begin{adjustwidth}{...}{...} or \hspace depending on your macro library.

Table insertion

Build AST table node:

AST representation: environment: tabular with column spec.

Create minimal LaTeX string for the table and compute LaTeX character offsets.

Render modern HTML table in Visual with data-ast-path attributes on table, row, and cell nodes for mapping.

Insert both at same time: ast.applyPatch(insert table at path), then aceReplace to add LaTeX code, and re-render Visual.

Table context menu operations (add/delete/merge/unmerge/clear)

Always operate on AST table node:

Add row: insert a row child in the AST table node.

Merge: replace multiple cell nodes with a multicolumn/multirow macro representation in AST and update HTML cell colspan/rowspan.

After AST change: render minimal affected table (update that table DOM), then aceReplace only the LaTeX for the table region.

5 ‚Äî Undo / Redo (professional-grade)

Options

History stack of AST patches (preferred): store inverse patches so undo just applies inverse patch. Each user action becomes one atomic patch.

Operation composition & coalescing: Coalesce proximate typing edits into a single history entry (e.g., typing letters within 1.5s become one operation). For structured edits (format apply), create single patch per toolbar click.

Redo stack: standard redo by pushing popped patch to redo stack.

Why AST patches? They‚Äôre semantic, safe, and let you revert macro-level changes cleanly.

Implementation sketch

class HistoryEngine {
  undoStack = [];
  redoStack = [];
  push(patch, inversePatch) { this.undoStack.push({patch, inversePatch}); this.redoStack = []; }
  undo() {
    const entry = this.undoStack.pop();
    if (!entry) return;
    ast.applyPatch(entry.inversePatch);
    this.redoStack.push(entry);
    reRenderDelta(entry.inversePatch.affectedPaths);
    aceReplace(...); // minimal
  }
  redo() { /* symmetric */ }
}

6 ‚Äî Practical React + Ace integration snippets

Important: These are skeletons demonstrating flow.

DualEditor container (pseudo)

function DualEditor() {
  const [ast, setAst] = useState(parseLatexToAst(initialLatex));
  const aceRef = useRef();
  const visualRef = useRef();
  const history = useRef(new HistoryEngine());

  // render initial
  useEffect(() => {
    renderVisualFromAst(ast, visualRef.current);
    aceRef.current.setValue(astToLatexString(ast));
  }, []);

  // Called when Visual user makes an edit
  function onVisualEdit(domRange, newDomFragment) {
    const start = mapDomRangeToAstPosition(domRange.start);
    const end = mapDomRangeToAstPosition(domRange.end);
    const newAstFragment = converter.htmlFragmentToAst(newDomFragment);
    const patch = { type: 'replace', start, end, newFragment: newAstFragment };
    const inverse = ast.computeInversePatch(patch);
    ast.applyPatch(patch);
    history.current.push(patch, inverse);
    const latexForPatch = astToLatexFragment(newAstFragment);
    const aceRange = astRangeToAceRange(start, end);
    aceRef.current.session.replace(aceRange, latexForPatch); // minimal replace
    renderVisualDelta(patch);
  }

  // Called when Ace user makes an edit
  function onAceChange(delta) {
    // delta contains start, end, newText
    const patch = convertAceDeltaToAstPatch(delta, ast);
    const inverse = ast.computeInversePatch(patch);
    ast.applyPatch(patch);
    history.current.push(patch, inverse);
    renderVisualDelta(patch);
  }

  return <>
    <Toolbar ...handlers... />
    <AceEditor ref={aceRef} onChange={onAceChange} />
    <VisualEditor ref={visualRef} onEdit={onVisualEdit} />
  </>;
}


Key helpers to implement: mapDomRangeToAstPosition, astRangeToAceRange, convertAceDeltaToAstPatch, renderVisualDelta.

7 ‚Äî Table features & UI behavior (MS Word-like expectations)

Visual UI design notes

Insert table: show a small grid picker to pick rows/cols, then create a modern HTML table with editable cells, placeholder cells empty and focus first cell.

Context menu on table right-click or cell toolbar with actions:

Add Row Above / Below

Add Column Left / Right

Delete Row / Delete Column

Merge Cells (when multi-select cells) / Unmerge

Delete Table

Clear Content (per row/col or selected cells)

When the user edits visually (typing in a cell), only that cell‚Äôs AST node is patched.

Merge/Unmerge: modify AST to include \multirow/\multicolumn or conceptual merged-cell nodes, and map to HTML rowspan/colspan.

UX details

Use a lightweight overlay toolbar that appears when a cell or row is selected with actions.

Keyboard: Tab moves to next cell, Shift+Tab to previous. Enter makes a new paragraph inside cell.

8 ‚Äî Edge cases & gotchas

Ambiguous mappings: Some HTML style combos don‚Äôt have direct LaTeX macros (e.g., CSS-only alignment). Use custom macros or wrapper environments to preserve semantics.

Round-trip fidelity: Keep original LaTeX comments, whitespace? Decide on policy. If comments must be preserved, store them in AST nodes and round-trip them.

Partial re-parsing: Full re-parse on every keystroke is heavy. Use incremental parsing or only re-parse affected environment region (the SyncEngine should compute a safe parse window).

Performance: For large docs, rendering full DOM is heavy. Render lazily and only update affected subtrees.

Complex LaTeX macros: User macros may not be representable ‚Äî offer graceful fallback (render as verbatim or show uneditable token).

Tables with complex colspan/rowspan: Ensure consistent model for merged cells in AST (use placeholder nodes in grid to indicate merged: merged: true, master: [r,c]).

9 ‚Äî Implementation roadmap (milestones)

Core AST & one-way conversion: parse LaTeX ‚Üí AST ‚Üí HTML render (readonly).

Ace ‚Üí AST sync: detect Ace edits ‚Üí patch AST ‚Üí update visual (one-directional).

Selection mapping: implement data-ast-path and basic selection mapping.

Visual editing ‚Üí AST: support basic text edits and small inline formatting (bold/italic).

Toolbar commands: implement bold/italic/list/indent/align using AST transforms.

Undo/Redo: history engine with patches.

Table insertion & context menu: full table manager, merge/unmerge.

Performance & incremental parse optimizations.

Edge-case handling & UX polish.

10 ‚Äî Tools / libraries to consider (implementation suggestions)

LaTeX parsing: latex.js (JS LaTeX parser), or server-side pandoc / plasTeX if you need robust parsing. If you need macros support they may require configuration.

Renderer: use your own renderer from AST to React components for complete control.

Editor: AceEditor for LaTeX. For visual: contenteditable with careful selection handling, or a lightweight WYSIWYG engine that you control.

Diff/patch: Use a small diff library for text ranges or implement AST-patch structures for safety.

(If you‚Äôd like, I can look up current best-in-class JS LaTeX parsers and give specific library names and pros/cons ‚Äî say ‚Äúyes, scan libraries‚Äù.)

11 ‚Äî Example: Bold command end-to-end (pseudo)

User selects range in visual and clicks Bold.

Flow:

Visual selection ‚Üí mapDomRangeToAstPosition ‚Üí startPos, endPos.

newAstFragment = wrapAstRangeWithMacro(startPos, endPos, 'textbf').

patch = { replace: [startPos, endPos], with: newAstFragment }

inverse = ast.computeInversePatch(patch)

ast.applyPatch(patch) ‚Üí history.push(patch, inverse)

renderVisualDelta(patch) ‚Üí update HTML only for nodes under affected path.

latexFragment = astToLatexString(newAstFragment)

aceRange = astRangeToAceRange(startPos, endPos)

ace.session.replace(aceRange, latexFragment)

12 ‚Äî Testing checklist

Cursor mapping: random positions in visual ‚Üí verify Ace cursor is in the corresponding LaTeX location.

Small edits in Visual update Ace with minimal replacement (not whole document).

Table insertion results in modern HTML table + correct LaTeX inserted at correct location in Ace.

Merge/unmerge produce correct LaTeX (\multicolumn, \multirow) and reflect in HTML colspan/rowspan.

Undo/redo revert both views consistently.

Formatting nesting: applying bold then italic then removing inner formatting produces correct LaTeX nesting.

Large document performance tests: typing, copy/paste, selection replace.

13 ‚Äî Deliverables I can provide next (pick any)

A scaffold React component (DualEditor) + utilities to wire Ace and a simple Visual editor (contenteditable) with selection mapping prototype.

An AST schema draft (JSON) and examples for tables, environments, macros.

Detailed code for mapDomRangeToAstPosition and astRangeToAceRange.

A working example for Insert Table (HTML generation + LaTeX snippet + Ace replace).
additionalNotes:
Most important every options are same behaviour like micro soft word document

Responsive design

title: smartmeal
description:
Overview

SmartMeal is an AI-powered mobile application designed to help users manage their daily diet, nutrition, and health goals effectively. It combines artificial intelligence, meal tracking, and augmented reality (AR) to deliver a personalized and engaging healthy lifestyle experience.

Main Objective

To create an intelligent app that:

Suggests healthy recipes based on user preferences.

Tracks daily meals and calories.

Generates personalized diet plans.

Uses AI and AR to improve food selection and awareness.

Key Features / Modules
1. User Authentication Module

Login / Register (Email, Google, or Social Login)

Profile Setup (Age, Weight, Height, Goals)

Secure data storage for each user

2. Dashboard (Central Hub)

Displays calorie summary, daily goal progress, and shortcuts

Links to all main modules: Recipe, Tracker, AI Chatbot, AR Scanner, Diet Plan, and Analytics

3. Recipe Module

AI suggests recipes based on user‚Äôs dietary preferences and restrictions

Users can view ingredients, preparation steps, and nutritional info

Option to save or favorite recipes

4. Meal Tracker Module

Log daily meals and snacks

Automatically calculates calories and nutrients

AI reminders for missing meals or hydration

5. AI Chatbot Module

Smart assistant that answers nutrition-related questions

Helps plan meals and motivates users to stay on track

6. Diet Plan Module

Personalized diet plans based on BMI, goals (weight loss, gain, or maintenance)

Weekly meal schedule

Option to adjust plan manually

7. AR Scanner Module

Users can scan real food using phone camera

App identifies food and provides calorie + nutrition info instantly

8. Profile & Analytics Module

Shows weight progress, calorie history, and activity trends

Graphs and charts for easy understanding

9. Settings Module

Notification preferences

Data privacy and sync options

App theme customization

Technology (for AI App Builder setup)

Frontend: Flutter / Dart (for cross-platform mobile app)

Backend: Firebase (for Authentication, Database, Storage)

AI Integration: OpenAI API / Gemini / Hugging Face (for chatbot and recipe recommendations)

AR: Google ARCore or camera-based scanning feature

title: pathnext
description:
Description	

Background
India‚Äôs skilling ecosystem offers a wide variety of vocational qualifications and training programs, but learners often face difficulty in choosing the right training pathway aligned with their background and career aspirations. Presently, the learning journey is mostly generic and not tailored to individual needs, which leads to skill mismatches and underutilization of training opportunities.

At the same time, industry requirements are evolving rapidly due to technological disruptions, future skills demand, and global competitiveness. To ensure employability, lifelong learning, and stackable skill progression, there is a strong need for an AI-enabled personalized guidance system that can dynamically recommend vocational pathways.

As the national regulator, NCVET aims to leverage AI to design solutions that bridge this gap by providing learners with customized training journeys mapped to the National Skills Qualifications Framework (NSQF) and real-time labour market demands.

Description
The challenge is to develop an AI system capable of:
Analyzing learners‚Äô profiles (academic background, prior skills, socio-economic context, learning pace, and aspirations).
Mapping career aspirations with industry-driven skill requirements and NSQF-aligned programs.
Generating adaptive, personalized training pathways including courses, micro-credentials, certifications, and on-the-job training opportunities.
Continuously updating recommendations as learners progress or as job market¬†trends¬†evolve.

title: social blog
description:
A simple blogging platform where users can view, add, and delete blog posts. Can be extended with login system and database.





Homepage lists all blog posts



Click to view full post



Admin can log in to create/edit/delete post



Posts stored in database (MongoDB/MySQL)



Public users can read blogs
additionalNotes:
**Situation**
You are building a blogging platform that serves two user types: public readers who browse and view posts, and administrators who manage content. The platform needs to handle core CRUD operations for blog posts with potential for future expansion to include user authentication and persistent data storage.

**Task**
Design and develop a blogging platform with the following core features:
1. A homepage that displays a list of all blog posts with titles and excerpts
2. Individual post pages that show the complete blog post content when clicked
3. An admin interface where authenticated administrators can create, edit, and delete blog posts
4. A backend system that stores and retrieves blog posts from a database (MongoDB or MySQL)
5. Public read-only access for non-authenticated users to view all posts and full content

**Objective**
Create a functional, scalable blogging platform that separates public viewing capabilities from administrative content management, with a foundation that allows future integration of user authentication and enhanced database functionality.

**Knowledge**
- The platform should prioritize simplicity in the initial build while maintaining an architecture that supports future extensions
- Public users should have unrestricted read access to all published posts without requiring authentication
- Admin functionality should be protected and only accessible to authorized users
- The database layer should be flexible enough to support both MongoDB and MySQL implementations
- Post data should include at minimum: title, content, creation date, and last modified date
- The homepage should present posts in a user-friendly format with clear navigation to individual posts

description:
Create a responsive, modern, and mobile-friendly **homepage for an agricultural AI web app called "GreenLens AI"**.

> - Clean, minimalist layout with a fresh green/agricultural color palette (use shades of green, white, and soft earth tones).

>   - Subtitle: **"Harness the power of AI to grow healthier crops, predict harvest quality, and protect your plants."**

>   Button: "Try Now" (link to `/melon`)  
>   
>   **Card 2 ‚Äì Plant Health Diagnoser**  
>   Icon: üå±

title: TrackTire
description: a dedicated web application designed for automotive workshops to replace fragmented paper systems with a single, authoritative digital repository for all vehicle service history. Its core function is to allow technicians to easily create VIN-centric digital job cards for every visit, accurately logging mileage, parts, and labor, with the critical output being the ability to instantly generate a comprehensive, branded Service Dossier (a single PDF document) that compiles the vehicle's entire maintenance timeline, providing customers with a professional, verifiable record that builds trust and enhances vehicle value.

title: Share&Study
description:
Build an Academic Resource and Notes Sharing Website for Student Clubs

Website Purpose:
Create a centralized, user-friendly platform for students and club members to upload, download, and organize academic notes, exam papers, study resources, and presentations. The site should help users search for materials by department, subject, resource type, and enhance collaboration within the student community.

Core Features to Include:

Homepage

Welcome message explaining the site‚Äôs purpose.

Quick navigation (menu or sidebar) to subjects and departments.

Highlights: recently added resources, most downloaded files.

Resource Database/Library

Structured table or folders to store all resources.

Columns/fields:

Title

Subject/Department

Resource Type (Notes, PPT, Exam Paper, etc.)

Contributor‚Äôs Name

Upload Date

Download/View Link

File attachment capability (PDF, DOCX, slides, images).

Upload/Contribution Portal

Clear "Upload" button or section for new contributions.

Easy form to collect info: title, subject, type, contributor details, file upload.

Instructions/guidelines for file format and naming conventions.

Browsing, Search, and Filters

Ability to filter resources by subject, department, year, and resource type.

Full-text search bar for quick access.

Tags or grouping to simplify navigation.

User Roles and Permissions

Contributors can upload, edit, and organize content.

Viewers (members, students) can browse and download.

Private and public sharing options‚Äîcontrol which content is club-exclusive or open to all.

Resource Showcase and Analytics (Bonus)

Top contributor leaderboard or acknowledgement.

Dashboard to show total uploads, downloads, and most popular files.

Option for users to rate or comment on resources.

Help & Contact

Page for FAQs, contact info, and contribution guidelines.

Style, Branding, and Usability:

Use club/college colors, logo, and event images for branding.

Make sure the layout is responsive‚Äîworks on desktop and mobile.

Visual clarity: clean menus, simple resource card or list view.

title: Finance
description:
1. Authentication (/login)

Username + Password login form.

On success ‚Üí redirect to /dashboard.

On failure ‚Üí toast: "Invalid credentials".

Role-based access: Admin, Accountant, Viewer.

UI elements gated by role.

Redux-managed authentication state.

2. Dashboard (/dashboard)

Show totals: Total Amount, Total Income, Total Outcome, Not Paid.

Quick cards ‚Üí /dashboard/daily-paid, /dashboard/15-days-paid, /dashboard/monthly-paid, /dashboard/yearly-paid.

Redux-managed totals update instantly when persons, loans, or transactions are added, approved, or updated.

3. Dedicated Payment Pages

Routes:
/dashboard/daily-paid, /dashboard/15-days-paid, /dashboard/monthly-paid, /dashboard/yearly-paid.

Features:

Reusable PaymentsTable component with filterType prop.

Table Columns: Name, Loan Type, Amount Paid, EMI Due Date, Payment Date, Payment Method, Status, Actions.

Actions: View Details, Approve Payment, Reject Payment, Mark Fully Paid.

Filters: Name, Loan Type, Status, Village, District, Date Range.

Redux-connected ‚Üí updates Dashboard totals, Calendar, Accounts, Transactions automatically.

Export: CSV, PDF, JPG.

4. Person Management
4.1 Add Person

Form Fields:

Name, DOB (auto-age), Village, District, Pincode, Address

Mobile Number, Alternate Number, Email

Person Photo (upload + preview), Aadhaar Upload, Bond Documents (multiple uploads)

Loan Details:

Loan Type (Daily, 15-Days, Monthly, Yearly)

Loan Amount

Rate of Interest (%)

EMI Schedule:

Schedule Type, Start Date, End Date, Frequency

Auto-generate Installments: Installment No., Due Date, Amount, Status (default = Not Paid)

Save Action:

Save ‚Üí Redux (personsSlice, loansSlice) + localStorage.

Toast: ‚úÖ "Person saved successfully. Awaiting approval."

Do not update Dashboard, Payments, or Calendar yet (approval pending).

4.2 Pending Approvals

Table: Name, DOB, Age, Loan Info, EMI Start Date, Status

Actions: Approve, Reject.

Approve Logic:

Updates Redux ‚Üí personsSlice: set status = Approved

Update all pages (Dashboard totals, Payment tables, Calendar, Transactions, Accounts, Reports) with new person + EMI schedule

Toast confirmation: ‚úÖ "Person approved and data propagated."

Reject Logic: removes person from pending list, keeps in personsSlice as rejected.

4.3 All Persons (/documents/all)

Table: Name, DOB, Age, Loan Info, Docs Count, EMI Due / All Installments, Loan Status

Expandable rows/modal ‚Üí full EMI schedule per person

Installment No., Due Date, Amount, Paid Status, Paid Date, Payment Method

Actions: Details ‚Üí private page, Approve, Reject, Mark Fully Paid, Delete

Filters: Name, Loan Type, Status, Village, District, Pincode

Search option ‚Üí search by Name, Loan Type, Village, District, Pincode

Export: CSV, PDF, JPG

Redux-managed ‚Üí updates Dashboard, Calendar, Transactions

4.4 Person Private Page (/documents/:id)

Layout:

Company logo (left/right), Person Photo

Person Details below photo: Name, DOB, Age, Address, Mobile, Alternate Number, Email

EMI schedule table: Installment No., Due Date, Amount, Paid Status, Paid Date, Payment Method

Edit ‚Üí opens edit form, updates Redux + localStorage, propagates to all pages

Delete ‚Üí removes all person data; Transactions & Reminders moved to Accounts

Toasts/confirmations for all actions

5. Calendar (/calendar)

Calendar view of EMI due dates

Click date ‚Üí modal: Record Payment, Send Reminder, View Details, Edit Due

Payment includes Payment Method

Status: Paid / Partially Paid / Overdue / Not Paid

Calendar badges: Green = Paid, Orange = Partial, Red = Overdue, Blue = Upcoming

Filters: Schedule Type, Loan Type, Village, District, Status

Export: CSV, PDF, JPG

Redux-managed ‚Üí updates Dashboard, Loans, Transactions, Reminders

6. Accounts (/accounts)

Manage Income/Outcome, Transactions, Audit Trail

Deleted person data remains in Accounts

Track who paid ‚Üí simulated email/WhatsApp notifications

Charts: Bar, Pie, Line (Chart.js)

Redux updates Dashboard totals automatically

Export: CSV, PDF, JPG

7. Transactions (/transactions)

Master list of all transactions & payments

Show EMI status per person

Actions: Approve/Reject, Edit, Reverse, Link/Unlink Person

Filters: Name, Loan Type, Date Range, Status, Village, District

Redux-connected ‚Üí updates Dashboard, Accounts, Reports

Export: CSV, PDF, JPG

8. Reports (/reports)

Prebuilt: Paid vs Unpaid, Daily, 15-Days, Monthly, Yearly, Person-wise summary

Filters: Name, Loan Type, Status, Village, District, Date Range

Redux-managed (live data)

Export: CSV, PDF, JPG

9. Reminders (/reminders)

Upcoming dues from EMI schedules

Actions: Send Email/WhatsApp (simulated), Create/Edit/Delete reminders

Filters: Upcoming 7 / 15 / 30 days, Loan Type, Village

Redux-managed ‚Üí instant updates

Export: CSV, PDF, JPG

10. Rate Calculator (/rate-calculator)

Inputs: Principal, Rate, Mode, Frequency, Duration

Logic Corrected:

Returns calculated result only (no formula displayed)

Export: CSV, PDF, JPG

11. Admin Settings (/admin)

Manage Calendars, Reminder templates, Email/SMS configs, User roles/permissions

Upload company logos for documents

System defaults: Interest rates, EMI schedules, retention policies

12. UI/UX Requirements

Mobile-first responsive layout

Sidebar + Topbar with role-based quick actions

Reusable components: forms, tables, modals, charts

Toasts & confirmations for all actions

File uploads with previews

Real file exports: CSV, PDF, JPG

13. State Management (Redux Toolkit)

authSlice: Authentication + roles

dashboardSlice: Totals (amount, income, outcome, unpaid)

personsSlice: Persons, approvals, loan info, docs

loansSlice: EMI schedules, due dates, payments (who paid + timestamp + method)

transactionsSlice: All transactions

accountsSlice: Income/outcome, audit trail

remindersSlice: Upcoming dues, reminders

title: Ayurvedic
description:
AyurNutriCare ‚Äì Brief Prototype Overview

Purpose:
AyurNutriCare is a cloud-based software prototype designed for Ayurvedic dietitians to efficiently create and manage patient-specific diet plans. It integrates modern nutrient analysis with Ayurvedic principles such as Rasa (taste), Virya (hot/cold energy), digestibility, and Prakriti (body type). The tool reduces manual effort, ensures accuracy, and provides holistic dietary recommendations.

Core Features (6 Key Requirements):

Login Page ‚Äì Secure access for dietitians.

Dashboard ‚Äì Overview of patients, recent diet charts, and quick actions.

Patient Info + Body Condition ‚Äì Capture patient details, health metrics, and Ayurvedic body type.

Diet Plan Generator ‚Äì Generates nutritionally balanced, Ayurveda-compliant meal plans; optional PDF export.

Profile Page ‚Äì View and edit dietitian information.

Logout ‚Äì Secure session termination.

Tools & Technologies:

Purpose	Tool/Technology
Frontend / UI	React.js or Bubble.io
Routing & Navigation	React Router (React)
UI Styling	Tailwind CSS / Bubble visual editor
State Management / Data	React Context / localStorage
Database	Local JSON / Airtable (No-code)
AI / Diet Suggestions (Optional)	OpenAI GPT
PDF Export / Reporting	jsPDF (React) / Bubble plugin
Authentication	Mock Auth (React) / Bubble built-in auth
Step-by-Step Build Process
Step 1 ‚Äî Project Setup

Initialize React app (npx create-react-app) or Bubble.io project.

Set up folder structure (pages, components, context, data, utils).

Configure Tailwind CSS or Bubble visual editor.

Step 2 ‚Äî Login Page

Create login form (email + password).

Authenticate user (mock/localStorage) or Bubble built-in auth.

Redirect to Dashboard on success; show error on fail.

Test route protection for unauthenticated users.

Step 3 ‚Äî Dashboard

Layout: Header (user info + logout), Sidebar, Main content area.

Display: total patients, recent diets, patient cards with ‚ÄúGenerate Diet‚Äù button.

Style with clean, responsive design.

Step 4 ‚Äî Patient Information + Body Condition

Patient Form: Name, Age, Gender, Diet Habit.

Body Condition Form: Height, Weight, BMI (auto-calc), BP, Appetite, Sleep, Water Intake, Prakriti, Digestibility, Allergies.

Store in React Context/localStorage or Bubble DB.

Display patient details on Patient Detail page.

Step 5 ‚Äî Diet Plan Generator

Small food DB: nutrition values + Ayurveda tags.

Algorithm: distribute meals (Breakfast, Lunch, Snacks, Dinner), calculate calories/protein/carbs/fat.

Display: Table with meals, nutrient totals, Ayurveda badges.

Optional: Export PDF using jsPDF/Bubble plugin.

Test: Generate diet for multiple patients, adjust quantities, verify totals.

Step 6 ‚Äî Profile Page

Display dietitian info: Name, Email, Clinic.

Allow editing fields ‚Üí save changes ‚Üí reflect in header.

Step 7 ‚Äî Logout

Clear session/localStorage.

Redirect to login page.

Ensure protected routes cannot be accessed after logout.

Step 8 ‚Äî UI & UX Polishing

Use color-coded badges for Ayurveda: Hot=Red, Cold=Blue, Easy=Green.

Add hover effects, responsive tables, toast notifications for actions.

Step 9 ‚Äî Testing & Demo

Full workflow: Login ‚Üí Dashboard ‚Üí Add Patient ‚Üí Body Condition ‚Üí Generate Diet ‚Üí Profile Edit ‚Üí Logout.

Verify nutrient totals, Ayurveda tags, BMI calculation, and PDF export.

Prepare 60‚Äì90 second demo highlighting Ayurveda integration and professional UI.
additionalNotes:
Additional Notes for Prototype
üîπ 1. Keep it Minimal but Impressive

Judges will not expect a full product ‚Üí they want to see clarity of idea + working demo.

Focus on UI polish + smooth workflow over building a huge backend.

üîπ 2. Highlight Ayurveda Integration

Most diet apps only show calories/macros ‚Üí you must show Ayurveda-specific tags (e.g., Hot/Cold, Digestibility, Rasa).

This makes your solution stand out.

üîπ 3. Prepare a Small Food Database

Keep 15‚Äì20 foods only (Rice, Milk, Ginger, Apple, Paneer, etc.).

Each should have:

Calories, Protein, Carbs, Fat

Ayurveda tags (Hot/Cold, Easy/Hard digestible, Taste)

Store in a JSON file or Bubble database ‚Üí easy to manage.

üîπ 4. AI Integration (Optional but Killer)

Use OpenAI GPT or a simple rule-based generator to suggest meals.

Even if basic, label it as ‚ÄúAI-assisted Diet Planning‚Äù ‚Äì judges love AI buzzwords.

üîπ 5. UI/UX Tricks

Use cards, color badges, icons for quick visualization.

Example: üî¥ Hot Food | üîµ Cold Food | ‚úÖ Easy to Digest.

Keep everything responsive for mobile + web.

üîπ 6. Demo Preparation

Record a 1-2 min walkthrough video:

Login

Add patient ‚Üí fill body condition

Generate diet ‚Üí show nutrient + Ayurveda values

Export PDF

Logout

Judges can watch quickly and understand impact.

üîπ 7. Future Scope (for Q&A)

Integration with HIS/EHR in hospitals.

Expand food DB to 8,000+ items.

Add AI voice/chatbot for patients.

Compliance with HIPAA/AYUSH digital health rules.

üîπ 8. Best Tools to Use

React + Tailwind CSS ‚Üí professional, fast.

Bubble.io (no-code) ‚Üí fastest if coding time is short.

Airtable/Firestore ‚Üí lightweight DB for demo.

jsPDF / Bubble Plugin ‚Üí export diet charts.

OpenAI API ‚Üí AI suggestions (optional, but impactful).

title: social media
description: Build a real-time social media mobile app like Instagram using Firebase (Auth, Firestore, Storage, FCM). The app must support user registration, profile management, photo/video uploads, stories, likes, comments, direct messaging, push notifications, and search. The app should scale to production usage with real-time updates visible to all users, similar to Instagram‚Äôs core features. The backend should enforce Firebase security rules and integrate AI-based features such as toxic comment filtering and smart recommendations.

title: Custom Tailoring Boutique Management Application
description: The Custom-Tailoring Boutique Management System is a web-based application designed to streamline boutique operations by managing the entire workflow from order creation to delivery and billing. The system supports multiple roles: Designers create new orders, record customer measurements, specify fabric details, and mark embroidery requirements; Staff check material availability, move orders to Cutting or Embroidery stages, mark embroidery needs, deliver finished products, and update billing statuses; the Cutting Team cuts fabrics based on measurements and moves orders to Stitching; the Stitching Team stitches garments and marks them as ready for delivery; and the Admin oversees operations, manages users and stock, receives low-stock alerts, monitors reports, and uses a calendar interface to track all orders by due dates and stages. The system manages material availability by notifying the Admin when fabrics are low and preventing workflow bottlenecks. Orders flow seamlessly through stages: Order Created ‚Üí Material Check ‚Üí Embroidery (if needed) ‚Üí Cutting ‚Üí Stitching ‚Üí Ready for Delivery ‚Üí Delivered ‚Üí Billing Completed. Key features include order management, inventory checks, embroidery, cutting, and stitching workflows, delivery and billing management, a calendar view for order planning, report generation, user management, and notifications for low stock or overdue deliveries. Built using ReactJS/Next.js, Node.js, PostgreSQL (Supabase), and hosted on platforms like Vercel or AWS, the application ensures a centralized, efficient, and real-time solution for boutique operations, reducing manual tracking, improving staff coordination, and enhancing customer satisfaction with timely deliveries and accurate billing.

title: Community HelpHub
description:
now we are doing community help hub*Situation*
Community Help Hub is a comprehensive MERN Progressive Web Application designed to connect help seekers with verified volunteers across critical community service categories, operating in diverse connectivity environments with intelligent matching and robust support mechanisms.

*Task*
Develop a full-stack web application that:
- Implements secure, role-based user authentication system
- Creates an intelligent Volunteer Matching & Prioritization Algorithm (VMPA)
- Builds offline-first PWA functionality
- Develops AI-powered request processing modules
- Establishes a multi-role platform for Help Seekers, Volunteers, and Admins

*Objective*
Create a scalable, reliable digital ecosystem that efficiently connects community members in need with qualified volunteers through an intelligent, secure, and user-friendly platform.

*Knowledge*
Critical System Components:
- Support categories: medical, food, transport, teaching
- Volunteer verification process
- Location-based matching
- Real-time SMS/email notifications
- AI-driven category suggestions and sentiment detection
- Robust data privacy and security

Technical Stack:
- Database: MongoDB Atlas
- Backend: Express.js, Node.js
- Frontend: React.js
- Authentication: JWT, bcrypt
- Offline Support: Service Worker, IndexedDB
- Communication: Socket.IO, Twilio, Nodemailer
- Geolocation: Google Maps API
- AI Integration: TensorFlow.js/HuggingFace Transformers

Volunteer Matching Algorithm Parameters:
- Location proximity
- Volunteer skill matching
- Request urgency levels
- Dynamic scoring mechanism

Security Requirements:
- JWT authentication
- Bcrypt password hashing
- HTTPS implementation
- Comprehensive input validation
- Granular role-based access control

*Detailed Implementation Guidelines*:

1. Authentication Workflow:
- Implement multi-tier registration (Help Seeker, Volunteer, Admin)
- Use JWT with refresh token mechanism
- Apply bcrypt for password hashing
- Enforce strong password policies
- Implement role-based access control

2. Offline-First Strategy:
- Utilize Service Worker for background synchronization
- Implement IndexedDB for local data storage
- Create robust request queuing system
- Ensure seamless online/offline transition

3. Volunteer Matching Algorithm:
- Develop multi-factor scoring system
- Prioritize based on proximity, skills, and urgency
- Implement real-time matching logic
- Create fallback mechanisms for unmatched requests

4. AI-Powered Modules:
- Implement sentiment analysis for request categorization
- Develop intelligent request routing
- Create predictive matching suggestions
- Ensure privacy-preserving AI processing

5. Notification System:
- Multi-channel communication (SMS, Email, In-App)
- Personalized, context-aware messaging
- Implement retry and fallback mechanisms
- Respect user communication preferences

Security Imperatives:
- Implement helmet for secure HTTP headers
- Use express-rate-limit to prevent brute force
- Comprehensive input validation
- Regular security audits
- Encryption of sensitive data

Deployment Considerations:
- Containerize backend with Docker
- Use GitHub for version control
- Deploy frontend on Vercel/Netlify
- Host backend on Render/Railway
- Implement continuous integration/deployment

Performance Optimization:
- Lazy loading of components
- Efficient state management
- Minimized bundle size
- Progressive loading strategies

Recommended Development Approach:
- Agile sprint-based implementation
- Iterative feature rollout
- Continuous user feedback integration
- Robust testing at each stage

Critical Warning: Your implementation's success depends on meticulous attention to security, user experience, and seamless offline functionality. Prioritize these aspects in every development decision.
I‚Äôm building a MERN PWA called "Community Help Hub". Requirements:
- Roles: Help Seeker, Volunteer, Admin
- Request categories: medical, food, transport, teaching
- Offline-first with IndexedDB and service worker; background sync
- Twilio for SMS, Google Maps for location/distance
- JWT auth, bcrypt passwords, role-based access
- AI modules for category suggestion and sentiment detection

Produce:
1. A prioritized implementation roadmap with sprint-by-sprint tasks.
2. Exact DB schemas (Mongoose) for User, Request, VolunteerStatus, AuditLog.
3. API specification (path, method, body, response, auth).
4. VMPA algorithm pseudocode and an example JS implementation.
5. Service worker & IndexedDB sync code skeleton.
6. Notification flows and message templates for SMS and email.
7. Security checklist with concrete code examples for JWT, refresh tokens, and input validation.
8. A minimal test plan (unit, integration, e2e) with example tests.

Return only JSON with keys: roadmap, schemas, apis, vmpa, sw_idb, notifications, security, tests.

title: Crisp
description:
Goal: Build a React app that works as an AI-powered interview assistant. It must:
Provide two tabs: Interviewee (chat) and Interviewer (dashboard). Both stay synced.
‚óè Interviewee (chat)
‚óã Let a candidate upload a resume (PDF required, DOCX optional).
‚óã Extract Name, Email, Phone from the resume; if anything is missing, the chatbot
collects it before starting the interview.
‚óã Run a timed interview where AI generates questions and judges answers.
‚óè Interviewer (dashboard)
‚óã List of candidates ordered by score.
‚óã Ability to view each candidate's chat history, profile, and final AI summary.
‚óè Persist all data locally so closing/reopening restores progress.
‚óè Support pause/resume with a Welcome Back modal.

Core Requirements
‚óè Resume Upload: Accept PDF/DOCX. Extract following fields - Name, Email, Phone.
‚óè Missing Fields: Chatbot prompts candidates to fill gaps before the interview starts. Like
if the phone number is missing, it should 1st ask for it before starting the interview.
‚óè Interview Flow
‚óã AI will dynamically generate questions for full stack (React/Node) role 1 by 1
‚óã 6 questions total: 2 Easy ‚Üí 2 Medium ‚Üí 2 Hard.
‚óã Questions are shown one at a time in the chat.
‚óã Timers per question: Easy 20 s, Medium 60 s, Hard 120 s.
‚óã When time runs out, the system automatically submits the answer and moves on.
‚óã After the 6th question, the AI calculates a final score and creates a short
summary of the candidate.
‚óè App contains Two Tabs
‚óã Interviewee Tab
‚ñ† Candidate chat flow ‚Äî questions, answers, timers, and progress.
‚óã Interviewer Tab (Dashboard)
‚ñ† Shows a list of all candidates with their final score and summary.
‚ñ† Clicking on a candidate opens a detailed view showing all questions,
answers, and AI scores for that candidate.
‚ñ† Search and sort functionality included.

‚óè Persistence (Data Storage)
‚óè Use any state management lib to save all timers, answers, and progress locally.
‚óè If a candidate refreshes or closes the page, everything is restored on reopening.
‚óè Show a ‚ÄúWelcome Back‚Äù modal for unfinished sessions.

Tech
‚óè You are free to use any libraries or tools you prefer.
‚óè Suggested stack: React + Redux (state & persistence, e.g., redux-persist /
IndexedDB).
‚óè Suggested UI: Ant Design or shadcn (or any other modern UI library).
‚óè Build a clean, responsive UI (basic chat + tables).
‚óè Implement friendly error handling (invalid files, missing fields)

title: Bold and Italic format style applied in LaTex
description:
Design a user interface that incorporates two main components: the Ace Editor for LaTex content and a Visual Editor for HTML display. The UI should include the following features:

Toggle Buttons:

Implement two toggle buttons at the top of the interface.
The first button switches between Ace Editor with LaTex content and the Visual Editor.
The second button toggles the Visual Editor on and off.
Content Transformation:

The LaTex content within Ace Editor should be transformed into HTML format and rendered in the Visual Editor.
Changes made in the Visual Editor should directly map to alterations in the LaTex content within Ace Editor, ensuring synchronization between the two views.
Styling Buttons:

Integrate buttons for ‚ÄòBold‚Äô, ‚ÄòItalic‚Äô, ‚ÄòSubscript‚Äô, ‚ÄòSuperscript‚Äô, and ‚ÄòUnderline‚Äô, similar to Microsoft Word functionality.
Styles applied in the Visual Editor must first edit the LaTex content in Ace Editor, following this pattern:
Visual Editor: Apply ‚ÄòBold‚Äô to ‚Äúname‚Äù -> Ace Editor: Transform ‚Äúname‚Äù to \textbf{name}.
Functionality Example:

When text is selected in the Visual Editor, applying styles like ‚ÄòBold‚Äô should result in the corresponding LaTex markup in Ace Editor. For instance, editing ‚Äúmy name ander‚Äù to ‚Äúmy \textbf{name} ander‚Äù in Ace Editor reflects as styled text in the Visual Editor.
Ensure that the transformation maintains content integrity and style consistency across both editing modes. Consider using libraries or frameworks that facilitate real-time syncing and styling transformations between LaTex content and HTML representation.

title: e-class
description:
Instead of just treating notes as files, think of them as an interconnected knowledge base. This is the most significant upgrade to your organization.

Platform: Notion (recommended for its flexibility and search) or Google Sites.

The Concept: Create an Index Page that serves as the main gateway to all course material. Each subject, unit, and concept gets its own linked page.

Why it's better:

Context: You don't just upload the PPT-Unit5.pptx; you create a page called "Unit 5: P-N Junctions" and embed the PPT, paste the relevant coding examples, and add a few bullet points of required reading. Everything is consolidated.

Supreme Search: You can search for a keyword (like "capacitance") and it will find the word whether it's in a header, a sentence, or a document name‚Äîmuch more powerful than basic folder search.

Interconnectivity: You can easily create links between related topics, helping you study how different concepts connect.

2. The Project System: The S.T.U.D.Y. System
This idea is about creating a reliable workflow‚Äînot just a folder structure‚Äîto ensure the organization actually happens.

Rotating "Digital Librarian": Appoint one student each week as the "Librarian." Their sole, brief job is to monitor the WhatsApp group and make sure every new instruction, PDF, or code snippet is immediately uploaded to the correct location in the Notion/Drive system.

Benefit: This prevents burnout on the student leader and guarantees 100% compliance, eliminating the frustrating backlogs.

"One-Minute Demo" for Teachers: The biggest barrier is often getting teachers to change their habit.

The Idea: Create a very short, silent, 60-second screen recording that shows them exactly how to upload a file to the dedicated subject folder. Focus on making the new method faster than sending it on WhatsApp.

Benefit: Reduces the effort required by the teachers, increasing adoption dramatically.

3. The Immediate Action Idea: Proactive Pinning
This is an idea you can start today to mitigate the current chaos while you build the long-term solution.

Pinning Protocol: Use the WhatsApp group's Pin Message feature to keep the two most critical items visible at the top of the chat at all times:

The link to the main Digital Organizer (Notion/Drive).

The most urgent or important announcement (e.g., "Exam on Friday" or "Lab Report Due Tomorrow").

Group Discipline: Train yourself and your classmates to immediately Star/Favorite any incoming file or instruction. This creates a personal, searchable list within WhatsApp for quick access without having to scroll through hundreds of messages.
additionalNotes:
I. Structured Note-Taking Systems (Beyond Basic Outline)
These methods integrate organization into the actual note-taking process for better recall and synthesis.

1. The Cornell Method (Optimized for Review)
This is an excellent way to structure your notes for active review, which is a key part of organization.

Page Layout: Divide your page into four sections:

Notes Column (Right, largest section): Where you take your primary notes during the lecture.

Cue/Keywords Column (Left, narrow section): Immediately after the lecture (or as you review), write keywords, potential test questions, or main ideas here. This is the index for your notes.

Summary Section (Bottom): Write a 2-3 sentence summary of the entire page's content at the bottom. This forces you to process and condense the main ideas.

Title/Date (Top): Course, date, and topic.

2. Mind Mapping (Visual Knowledge Synthesis)
Instead of linear lists, mind maps show how concepts relate to one another, which is more powerful for holistic understanding.

Process: Start with the Central Topic in the middle of a page. Draw Main Branches for major concepts. Draw Sub-Branches for supporting details, definitions, and examples.

Organization: The map itself is the organization. You're organizing information by relationship rather than by sequence. Use different colors, icons, and arrows to show connections between different branches or even other notes.

3. Progressive Summarization (for Digital Notes)
This technique works best with digital notes (e.g., in a tool like Evernote, Notion, or OneNote) and turns notes into increasingly condensed review material.

Layer 1 (The Notes): Capture everything.

Layer 2 (Bolding): Immediately after the lecture, go through the notes and bold the most important keywords and phrases.

Layer 3 (Highlighting): Later, highlight only the most critical bolded phrases (the 'aha' moments).

Layer 4 (Summary/TOC): Create a bulleted summary or Table of Contents at the top of the page using only the highlighted points. Your future self only has to read this top section for a quick refresh.

II. Utilizing Advanced Digital Tools (Beyond File Sharing)
Tools like Notion, OneNote, and Trello go far beyond simple file storage. They offer database and collaborative features.

4. Creating a "Personal Knowledge Base" (PKB) with Notion
A PKB is a centralized, searchable repository for all your course material, not just notes. It acts as a customized, interconnected "digital textbook."

Central Course Dashboard: Create a single Notion Page for your semester.

Databases, not Folders: Instead of using folders, create a "Class Notes" database within your dashboard. Each lecture is an item in the database.

Properties: Use database tags/properties to categorize notes in multiple ways:

Status: (e.g., "In Progress," "Ready for Review," "Study Guide Complete")

Topic: (e.g., "Thermodynamics," "Renaissance Art," "Supply & Demand")

Assignment: (Link a note to a specific essay or project)

Links/References: (Add a section for related textbook pages, professor slides, or web links).

Bi-directional Linking: Mentioning the name of one note in another automatically creates a backlink, helping you see the web of connections between different topics and classes (e.g., linking a note on "Marxism" from your Sociology class to an essay you're writing in your English class).

Templates: Create a Notes Template (e.g., a pre-built Cornell layout) so every new lecture note has a consistent structure with just one click.

5. Using Google Sites for a Class "Wiki" (Collaborative)
If you have a study group, you can collectively turn your notes into a navigable website (a class wiki) using free tools like Google Sites or a shared Notion page.

Structure: Create a site with a main page for the course. Have a main section for each Unit/Module.

Wiki Articles: Each person is responsible for summarizing and presenting the notes for a specific lecture or topic as a clean, hyperlinked "wiki article."

Benefits: This turns note organization into an active learning/teaching task and provides a clean, searchable, and hyperlinked resource for everyone in the group.

III. Implementing "Librarian" Practices
Take inspiration from professional librarians and knowledge managers for organization that enhances retrieval and long-term utility.

6. Standardized Naming and Tagging (Metadata)
Professional librarians use metadata to ensure information is easy to find. You can do the same for your digital notes.

Consistent File Naming: Instead of Psych-Notes-10-14.docx, use a standardized format that sorts logically:

[Course Code]_[Unit/Topic]-[Date]_Description

Example: PSYC201_Cognitive-10252025_MemoryModels.pdf

Universal Tagging: Use a consistent set of keywords across all your tools (Notion tags, Zotero tags, file names) to cross-reference concepts. Examples: #Definition, #KeyExamConcept, #HistoricalContext, #Example.

7. The "Weekly Review" and Curation
An organized system is useless if you don't maintain it.

Schedule a Curation Time: Dedicate 30 minutes every week to be your own "Digital Librarian."

Process: Review all notes from the past week.

Curation: Clean up handwriting, fill in gaps, create the Cornell summary, bold/highlight key points, and ensure all digital notes are correctly tagged and filed into your Notion database.

Synthesis: Identify any connections between different course notes and create those bi-directional links.

Role:
You are an AI trading agent specialized in binary options trading on Pocket Option.
Your goal is to analyze given indicator values and produce clear CALL/PUT/NO TRADE signals with reasoning.
Always follow the strategy rules strictly.it automatically analysis the full assets and give the signals.

RSI 14 (levels: 30 oversold, 70 overbought)

Bollinger Bands (Period 20, Deviation 2)

Price ‚â§ Lower Bollinger Band

RSI < 30 (Oversold)

Last candle bullish (green rejection)

PUT Entry:

Price ‚â• Upper Bollinger Band

RSI > 70 (Overbought)

Last candle bearish (red rejection)

NO TRADE if conditions are not fully met.

Trade only in London (7‚Äì11 UTC) or New York (12‚Äì16 UTC) sessions.

Avoid high-impact news events.

Max 5 trades per session.

title: defence report portal

additionalNotes:
Core Features

Secure Login & Role-Based Access

User roles: Defence User / CERT-Army Analyst.

Defence users log in with email + password (for hackathon demo).

CERT-Army analysts access dashboard with higher privileges.

Complaint Submission (Intake Form)

Upload options: text message, URL, image, PDF, or file.

Metadata: date, category (phishing, fraud, malware, suspicious).

Store complaints securely in database.

AI/ML Threat Analysis

Text: Use HuggingFace API ‚Üí classify as phishing/spam/normal.

URL: Check with VirusTotal API ‚Üí safe or malicious.

Files: Scan with ClamAV API or VirusTotal file scan.

Images/Videos (basic demo): Flag suspicious/fake content.

Assign risk score (High / Medium / Low).

Alerts & Mitigation Guidance

After AI analysis ‚Üí show alert result to user: ‚úÖ Safe / ‚ùå Malicious.

Provide playbook steps (e.g., ‚ÄúChange password‚Äù, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt click link‚Äù, ‚ÄúReport to bank‚Äù).

CERT-Army Dashboard

List of all complaints ‚Üí risk-ranked.

Filters by type (fraud, phishing, malware, espionage).

Ability to view forensic evidence.

Mobile-Ready

Web app must be responsive and accessible on smartphones.

Technical Approach

Frontend: React.js + TailwindCSS (modern, clean UI).

Backend: Django (Python, easy AI/ML integration) or Node.js (fast APIs).

Database: PostgreSQL (secure, scalable).

AI/ML Integration:

HuggingFace API (text classification).

VirusTotal API (URL + file scan).

ClamAV (file malware detection).

Security: Role-based access, AES-256 encrypted storage, HTTPS (TLS 1.3).

Workflow

Backend stores complaint ‚Üí runs AI/ML analysis.

AI model/API outputs ‚Üí classify as safe/malicious + risk score.

User sees alert + mitigation steps instantly.

CERT-Army analyst dashboard shows all incidents (ranked by risk).

title: Complaint Management System
description:
Prompt: A Comprehensive Complaint Management System
Project Title: Role-Based Complaint Management System using ReactJS.

Project Abstract:
This project is a modern, web-based complaint management platform designed for three key stakeholders: Users (e.g., students or residents), Super Admins, and Employees/Technicians. The system allows users to easily register complaints and track their status in real-time. Super Admins can manage all incoming complaints, assign them to the appropriate technicians, and oversee the entire workflow. Technicians can view their assigned tasks and update the status accordingly. The application is built with ReactJS, modern JavaScript, and communicates with a backend API to ensure seamless data management.

Key Features:
Role-Based Access Control:

User: Can create new complaints and view the status of their own submissions.

Super Admin: Has complete oversight. They can view all complaints, manage master data (like departments and users), and assign pending complaints to employees.

Employee/Technician: Can view only the complaints assigned to them and update the status (e.g., "In-Progress," "Completed").

User Authentication:

A secure system for users to create a new account (Signup) and log in.

Upon successful login, user details, including their role and a JWT token, are stored in localStorage to manage the session and authorize actions.

Complaint Management Workflow:

Users can submit a new complaint through a detailed form, specifying the block, room number, complaint type, and remarks.

The Super Admin has an interface to view all pending complaints and assign them to a specific employee from a predefined list.

Admin Master Dashboard:

A dedicated dashboard (MastersDashboard) for the Super Admin to manage all core application data, including Departments, Programmes, Blocks, Rooms, and User accounts.

Statistics Dashboard:

A visual dashboard that displays key statistics about the complaints, such as the total number of complaints, and the counts of those that are pending, assigned, and closed.

Interactive User Interface (UI):

The home page features an engaging, animated title using the ReactTyped library and a 3D tilt effect on mouse movement powered by Anime.js.

The application includes a theme toggle button, allowing users to switch between a light and dark mode for a better viewing experience.

Technology Stack:
Frontend: React.js, React Router DOM, Axios (for API calls), Anime.js (for animations).

Styling: CSS with logic for dynamic theming (Light/Dark modes).

Data Storage: Browser localStorage for session management and caching, in addition to a backend database.

Backend (Inferred): The application is configured to make API calls to a server running at http://localhost:5000, which suggests a backend built with a technology like Node.js/Express.js and a database like MongoDB.

Application Flow:
A new user lands on the Home page and navigates to the Signup page to create an account.

After signing up, the user goes to the Login page and enters their credentials.

Upon successful authentication, their role ("user") is identified, and they are redirected to the complaint submission form (/complaint).

The user fills out the complaint details and submits the form. The new complaint is saved in localStorage and sent to the backend database.

A Super Admin logs in and is directed to the MastersDashboard. From there, they can navigate to the ComplaintList page to see the new "Pending" complaint.

The Admin assigns this complaint to an available Employee (e.g., 'Joshua') using the assignment dropdown.

The Employee ('Joshua') logs in and is taken to their dedicated page (/employee), where they see only the tasks assigned to them. After resolving the issue, they update the complaint's status to "Completed".

The original user can now log in again to see that the status of their submitted complaint has been updated to "Completed."

title: Data Preprocessing
description:
Project Description (Python Stack)

The Invoice Data Extraction & Processing Software is designed to automate the extraction of key information (vendor name, invoice amount, and date) from invoices and store them in a structured format. Using Python as the primary technology, the system leverages OCR (Optical Character Recognition) tools like Tesseract OCR and PaddleOCR to recognize text from scanned or digital invoices.

The extracted data undergoes field validation (e.g., checking vendor names, validating amount formats, and date consistency) before being exported to structured storage systems such as PostgreSQL databases or CSV files.

To make the system accessible and easy to use, a lightweight Flask-based web application is implemented. This web interface allows users to upload invoices, trigger the OCR extraction process, and view or download the processed data.

Additionally, the solution ensures non-functional requirements such as OCR accuracy (by fine-tuning models and preprocessing invoice images) and secure storage of sensitive financial data.

üîß Tech Stack (Python-Focused)

OCR: Tesseract OCR, PaddleOCR

Backend: Python (Flask)

Database: PostgreSQL

Export Options: CSV / Database Integration

Additional Tools: Pandas (for data cleaning & exporting), OpenCV (for image preprocessing) use react for frontend

title: STEEL FLOW
description:
Data Sources: The system gets its information from three places: your company's SAP ERP system, existing Excel and CSV files, and external data like weather APIs.
Data Integration: All this raw data is automatically collected and stored in a central database, which acts as the single source of truth for the entire system.
Backend Intelligence: This is the "brain" of the solution. It has two main parts:
AI/ML Prediction Engine: A smart model that predicts potential vessel delays using historical data.
Optimization Engine: A powerful algorithm that uses all the data (including the AI's delay predictions) to calculate the cheapest and most efficient logistics plan.
Web Application: This is the software that connects everything. The backend (Django/Flask) processes all the data and runs the engines, while the frontend (React/Vue.js) is the user-friendly website where the logistics team can see dashboards, input data, and view the final optimized plan.
Cloud Deployment: The entire system is hosted on a cloud platform like AWS or Azure, which makes it reliable, scalable, and accessible from anywhere.

title: Blood Donation Tracker
description: The Blood Donation Tracker is a blockchain-based system designed to make the blood donation process more secure, transparent, and efficient. It addresses the major drawbacks of traditional centralized systems‚Äîsuch as data tampering, lack of trust, and slow donor-patient matching‚Äîby using blockchain technology to store all records in a decentralized and tamper-proof ledger. This ensures that donor, hospital, and patient information cannot be hacked or altered, and every blood unit can be tracked from the donor to the recipient. The system also uses smart contracts to automate approval and verification processes, reducing human error and increasing efficiency. By providing transparency, end-to-end traceability, and secure data management, the Blood Donation Tracker builds trust among all parties involved and encourages more people to participate in blood donation. Future enhancements include QR code tracking for each blood bag, a mobile app for donors to view their history, and a reward system to promote regular donations.
